FacilityName: ETC La Grange Gas Processing Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Energy Transfer Corporation (ETC) owns and operates a natural gas processing facility, the LaGrange Gas Processing Plant, located in Fayette County, Texas.  The plant is designed to process wellhead natural gas and recover liquid products from the gas by physical separation and cryogenic means, producing marketable pipeline quality natural gas.  The facility receives two phase flow (gas and liquids) from the inlet pipeline and both petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for off-site sales.

Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act applies to the LaGrange Gas Processing Plant because the plant handles and stores methane, ethane, propane, butane, isobutane, pentane, and isopentane in excess of threshold quantities.  Two requirements of this section specifically apply to operations at the plant:

1.  A?112(r) Purpose and General Duty Clause- The essence of the general duty clause is that an owner/operator that stores and uses hazardous chemicals in any quantity has a fundamental obligation to ensure a safe operation and protect individuals from the facility's hazards and to have plans in place in the event of an accident to appropriately manage the situation.  ETC is committed to ensuring the safe operation of the LaGrange Gas Processing Plant, as well as all of its other operations, to ensure a safe workplace for our employees and a safe location for our neighbors in the community.  ETC, therefore, has procedures in place to prevent accidents and is committed to emergency preparedness both for our facility and local community by coordinating with the Fayette County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

2.  Risk Management Plan - The LaGrange Gas Processing Plant processes natural gas, recovers natural gas liquids, and produces pipeline quality natural gas.  This process involves the handling and storage of chemicals, or flammable substances, in excess of thresholds specified in A?112(r). ETC management

is very aware of the potential hazards posed by the handling and storage of natural gas and natural gas liquids. Therefore, programs have been established to prevent any accidental releases and to train personnel for emergency response in the event of a release.  These programs are documented and described in this Risk Management Plan.



For planning purposes, ETC has considered the impact of a worst case scenario, defined to be a simultaneous catastrophic release of a 95,000 gallon bullet tank and 90,000 gallon bullet tank containing flammable liquid which results in a vapor cloud explosion.  Using the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA's) RMP*Comp methodology, a potential radius of impact due to the explosion was calculated to extend to a 0.80 mile radius.  Twenty (20) residential and seven (7) industrial public receptors have been identified to be located within this 0.8 mile radius. However, it should be noted that the probability of the worst-case catastrophic event evaluated in this report is extremely remote - far less than natural catastrophes such as tornadoes and floods that could produce much more severe and extensive damage and injury.  



ETC also considered the impact of a more likely release.  This alternative release is characterized as an accident during loading of liquids from a truck into one of the bullet storage tanks at the site.  If the truck driver failed to disconnect the transfer hose prior to departure, upstream piping and equipment could potentially be damaged, resulting in a release of a mixture of natural gas liquids under pressure.  The duration of this release could be up to ten minutes, based on the time needed to close valves.  Using RMP*Comp, the impact distance of a potential explosion of the vapor cloud formed after this release was calculated to be 0.30 miles.  There are three industrial receptors located within this radius.
